title: Sergeant John Sharp, radio operator who spent three months with the maquis in occupied France for Operation Jedburgh – obituary
text:
Sergeant John Sharp, who has died aged 96, was one of the last of the 300 officers and men of the wartime Operation Jedburgh, who dropped behind enemy lines to advise, train and lead local resistance forces, and who formed a band of brothers for the rest of their lives.

On the night of June 10-11 1944, Sharp parachuted on to the Morvan mountains in central France. He was the radio operator in a two-man Jedburgh team code-named Isaac; it was commanded by Lieutenant-Colonel James “Hutch” Hutchinson (later the Tory politician Sir James Riley Holt Hutchinson, 1st Baronet, DSO), accompanied by a 10-man SAS team on a separate mission.

The pilot of the bomber from which they jumped had failed to find...
description: Sergeant John Sharp, who has died aged 96, was one of the last of the 300 officers and men of the wartime Operation Jedburgh, who dropped behind enemy lines to advise, train and lead local resistance forces, and who formed a band of brothers for the rest of their lives.
